risinfo.chaptertitle: 20. Interviewing in Health, Medical, and Integrated Care Settings

sect1.title: Information Critical to Making a Diagnosis
sect1.para: A diagnostic interview interview that produces an accurate diagnosis is valuable for various reasons. It informs treatment planning, informs team members in both interdisciplinary and multidisciplinary settings about the patient and what may benefit their care (e. g., trauma-informed approach to physical exams, psychiatry medication management, cognition’s impact on retention of information, etc.), and of course, within the medical model, produces a billing code for insurance companies. The medical model has shifted the field of psychology considerably in that it relies on categorical labels to describe the patient experience. Medical providers and clinicians use Current Procedural Terminology (CPT) codes Current Procedural Terminology (CPT) codes to report services and determine reimbursement rates. According to American Psychological Association ( 2023 ), the three most common codes used by psychologists are Health and Behavior Assessment and Intervention (96156–96171), Psychotherapy Codes (CPT codes 90832–90863), and Psychological and Neuropsychological Testing Codes (CPT codes 96105–96146). There are also also Caregiver Behavior Management Training Codes, Consultation Codes, and more. Commonly within the healthcare setting, mental health codes are secondary to the medical diagnosis, which results in using Health and Behavior Assessment CPT codes.

Additionally, a psychologist should consider an individual’s past psychiatric diagnosis (diagnosis by history), rule-outs and differentials, and provisional and Z-code diagnosis when formulating a diagnostic impression. As previously stated, completing a chart review, obtaining collateral information, initiating an interview with the individual, noting observations, and conducting brief mood and cognitive screeners provide a psychologist with the necessary information to form a comprehensive diagnosis and treatment planning.

sect2.title: Diagnosis by History
sect2.para: Diagnosing mental health health conditions by history involves the individual’s past and present experiences, behaviors, and symptoms. Reviewing past interviews with the individual and identifying their subjective experiences, including mood, thought patterns, behavior changes, and functional impairments, can give the psychologist a starting point of what symptomology may resurface or progress and help distinguish between acute, episodic, and chronic conditions. Additionally, identifying past past family medical and psychiatric history and the individual’s social and developmental history may help identify potential genetic and environmental influences. The benefits of accessing this information include helping the psychologist and healthcare team identify factors contributing to or exacerbating the individual’s mental and physical health. Identifying past mental health and comorbid diagnoses also facilitates the development of a treatment plan that addresses the the unique needs of the individual.

sect2.title: Differentials and Rule-Outs
sect2.para: Differential and rule-out Differential and rule-out diagnoses involve distinguishing between two or more conditions that share similar symptoms to arrive at the most accurate diagnosis. This process requires a systematic approach with careful consideration of all possible diagnoses. The key steps involved include reviewing the individual’s symptoms: duration, severity, nature, and impact on daily life. Next, identify possible physical health conditions that could mimic psychiatric symptoms (e. g., neurological conditions and thyroid disorders), which a medical health professional can further examine examine for appropriate evaluation. In addition to ruling out, a psychologist would also examine comorbidities. Identifying and evaluating co-occurring conditions may aid or complicate the proposed treatment planning and diagnosis. For example, the patient in case example one had a medical condition of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) . Most often, a diagnosis of COPD is comorbid with an anxiety-related mental health diagnosis. Additionally, there is a bi-directional relationship where the symptoms of anxiety may exacerbate the symptoms of COPD and vice-versa. Accurately diagnosing and treating the primary condition and comorbidities improves improves the prognosis and overall quality of life for the individual.

sect2.title: Provisional Diagnosis
sect2.para: Provisional diagnoses diagnoses are temporary when sufficient evidence suggests a particular disorder, but confirmatory data is pending (e. g., medical or specialized psychiatric/neuropsychological examinations). Provisional diagnoses allow the psychologist to begin treatment with the best data and information available. Early treatment and intervention can significantly impact prognosis. As treatment takes effect, the diagnostic picture may become more apparent, allowing the psychologist to make further adjustments to the diagnosis. Reviewing the treatment effects and outcomes ensures that the individual’s medical records accurately reflect their current medical status.

sect2.title: Z-Codes
sect2.para: Z-codes Z-codes are part of the International Classification of Diseases, Tenth Revision, Clinical Modification (ICD-10-CM) and describe factors influencing the individual’s health status and contact with health services. Z-codes are important in the health care setting as they highlight psychosocial and medical issues, which can lead to better treatment outcomes. Using case example one, collaboration with the individual’s social work professional to address the distress caused by housing, Inadequate Housing (Z59.1) can help facilitate connecting the individual with community-based, older-adult older-adult housing options that also factor in her low socioeconomic status, Low Income (Z59.6) which may facilitate connection to additional resources the individual may or may not be aware of applying.

Using historical, differentials, rule-outs, provisional, and Z-code diagnoses is integral to a nuanced and dynamic approach to diagnosis. Psychologists in healthcare settings can provide personalized care that addresses several factors affecting an individual’s mental health. By leveraging these diagnostic elements, psychologists can ensure more comprehensive formulations that lead to more accurate diagnoses,tailored tailored treatment plans, and improved outcomes.
